advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666"> Our Peripheral Expansion System gives you plug-in cards for memory expansion, P-Code capabilities, a disk drive controler and the RS-232 interface. You can also add a modem, speech synthetiser, disk drive and matrix printer...<br><br> ... TI BASIC is built into the computer, but it can also handle TI Extended BASIC, UCSD Pascal, TI LOGO, TMS-9900 Assembly language and TI PILOT ... </font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SANCO BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> STICKER</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a promotional adhesive sticker of the RC 700 Piccolo... What a visionary thought!</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>The first sentence of this advert is:<br> <i>The new Commodore 64 is the most powerful personal computer available to the businessman.</i><br> Which wasn't totally true, even totally false.<br><br> The picture is also totally unrealistic. Each detail sounds false.<br> The C64 never was a business system, but a perfect home computer. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Tim_K for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> Z-2D ADVERT (1977)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Z-2D 1977 price list:<br><br> - Kit version with 1 F.D. drive: <b>$1495</b><br> - Assembled version: <b>$2095</b><br> - Additional F.D. drive: <b>$495</b> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ITALIAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.1000bit.net" target="_blank">www.1000bit.net</a> for this advert</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL LEAFLET #3</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LEAFLET (1982) - PAGE 3</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice that the box arts are completely different from the final ones (see software section)</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> APPLE BUSINESS GRAPHICS</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Apple graphics package was launched in September 1982. It was available for both the Apple II and Apple III.<br><br> Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">As you know, one picture is worth a few thousand numbers.<br> As you may not know, Apple Business Graphics software can generate more types of pictures, in more colours, using more data than any other graphics package... On the monitor of your choice. And on virtually any printer or plotter on the market...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.cobit.kit.net" target="_blank">COB-Clube Old Bits</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PRIMO ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ITALIAN AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>I bellissimi...<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>http://angelmemories.cjb.net/</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN LEAFLET #4</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CREATIVITY BUILT-IN</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a French advert from december 1985 for a special christmas pack : TO-7/70 + Microsoft Basic level 5 + tape recorder + Colorpaint + Basic initiation cube for "only" 3990 FF. <br><br> "All the world in a present"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>''The sound, the color, the intelligence''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to David Wilson for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE AD</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://club.pep.ne.jp/~p.katsu/pasocata/index.html">P.KATSU</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Carefully, one last time... I compared everything and I offered myself a BBC" <br><br> Lucky guy, he must be rich at more than 6300fr the BBC... At the end of the text we can read : <br><br> "The price : 6300fr maximum. Of course it's not given. More expensive than some (but I had already eliminated them)." !! <br><br> At least they are honest.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #3 (1979) </strong></font><br><blockquote>From Playboy December 1979. <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Peathead</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD (APR. 86)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>"A step toward the future" <br><br> Hmmmm.....</blockquote>

computer.builtInGames: 4 pongs games (Catch, Solitare, Super Pong and Pong)
computer.coprocessor: Power on/off, game selection, channel 3/4 switch for TV-output
computer.description:
The Super PONG (model C-140) is a follow up to the orignal Atari Pong (model C-100). Compared to its brother which could only play one game of pong, Super Pong offers 4 different pong games.
Like the C-100, the C-140 is based on an Atari pong-in-a-chip IC (C010073-01) which was revolutionnary for the time. The on-screen scoring as well was a feature scarcely found on other pong systems.
Like all first Atari pong systems, the C-140 was also sold by Sears. It was the same as Atari's model, but with detachable controllers, and a woodgrain style.
computer.language: 4 pongs games (Catch, Solitare, Super Pong and Pong)
computer.name: SUPER PONG (Model C-140)
